author: @Celeste-.-marie
text: You have inspired me to go for it. My background is healthcare in a patient care role for the last decade and I am ready for a change. I have free access to linkedin learning through my university log in so I started some data analyst modules there with the added bonus that I can get a certificate for my profile when I am done. I plan to start your bootcamp videos, and I have actually enrolled in a data analytics grad certificate that starts in Jan. I know a grad certificate probably isnt necessary, but I have a way to get it paid for, so it makes sense for me to do it. I havent seen much discussion on any of the grad certificates. Im curious what you think about those. It looks good- covers SQL, excel, tableau and power BI, and has a whole course on solving problems with data etc. Given that a grad cert would be directly relevant. Would move my education section up on my resume? Doing so through a university has the added benefit of building a network in the feild.

author: @patrickmeehan6856
text: Thanks for this!  Bolded key words, key word optimization, and using active verbs to lead off each bullet point will, like you said, help a resume get through those automated first rounds of resume selection at potential places of work.  Is there a way you could re-upload with "Assistant" , under Work Experience, spelled correctly?  I imagine most viewers will disregard your advice and just copy and paste it, assuming it is perfect, and an employer will immediately notice this misspelling.     Thanks, also, for the advice about how non-tech workers, like teachers, can produce a tech-adjacent resume.
